Sports make me sad

source

I tweeted this shortly after the San Francisco Giants won the World Series:

New York is slowly shutting down because a history making hurricane, but that's not nearly as important as baseball. Clearly.

— Oscar Bieber Godson (@oscargodson) October 29, 2012

And a good friend tweeted me back:

@oscargodson why does it piss you off so much? I mean, I'm jot into it, but it doesn't irritate me either.

— Daniel Erickson (@TechWraith) October 29, 2012

To be clear, sports don't piss me off, but it makes me sad and does irritate me a little. I constantly get flak from people on Twitter who ask why I shit on sports so much. I mean, it's just something to watch, right? No, not really. Do riots break out when a character dies in The Walking Dead? How about, do they break out and riot when anything at all is exciting on any TV show ever? Not that I can think of. So, clearly sports is pretty important to people, and this is where it makes me sad.

Do people break out in a riot when the government targets US citizens to be killed without any court review? Nope. What about when the government passed the Patriot act without even reading it allowing all kinds of civil liberties to be ignored by law enforcement? Still no. Anyone in my feed talk about the hurricane Sandy? No one for over an hour even mentioned it while NY subways were being closed down. Instead of "Breaking news: NY shutdown it's subway system" it was "breaking news: Giants win."

What really bothers me is sports is what we as a society decided is important. You know that feeling you get when a parent says something along the lines of, "I'm not angry, I'm just disappointed"? Yeah, that's how I feel. It's how I feel every time I see some asshole lighting a car on fire because their sports team won or even when some guy is yelling at his TV set because his team is losing. Or the worst, when a fan talks shit to a fan of another team of which neither of them have any affiliation with yet feels like he (who has done nothing but randomly choose a team), is superior.

It means absolutely nothing. It's less than nothing. There's no city wide fireworks or "breaking news" for vets coming home or when a scientific or medical break through happens. No, what's important to all of us is someone is really good at hitting a ball really far with a stick. That's what's important.
